item.title: The Collective
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
Our Mandate

The Flat is a collective that works to encourage cycling through the sharing of knowledge and tools.

The Flat Bike Collective seeks to

Make bicycling more accessible by
- sharing repair facilities and knowledge
- offering workshops to persons of all skill levels
- reducing the costs of bike maintenance

Providing a welcoming environment by
- recognizing the existence of power imbalances
- encouraging dialogue and diversity of opinion
- confronting discriminatory actions and words
- making decisions by consensus

Minimize our environmental impact by
- recycling and reusing parts
- promoting cycling as a viable mode of transportation

Promote a greater sense of community by
- making our resources available to groups on and off campus
- supporting bike-related projects and events
- collaborating with other bike organizations

View the Flat's Constitution and Mandate (updated Oct. 2023. English only)

Franais

The Flat est un atelier de rparation de vlos coopratif visant encourager le cyclisme par le partage des connaissances et des outils.

Latelier coopratif The Flat cherche

Rendre le cyclisme plus accessible :
- en partageant des installations de rparation et des connaissances
- en offrant des ateliers toute personne dsireuse dapprendre, quelle soit exprimente ou non
- en rduisant le cot dentretien des vlos

Offrir un environnement accueillant :
- en reconnaissant lexistence du dsquilibre des forces
- en encourageant le dialogue et la diversit dopinions
- en agissant contre les actions et les mots discriminatoires
- en prenant des dcisions par consensus

Minimiser notre impact sur lenvironnement :
- en recyclant et en rutilisant des pices de vlo
- en promouvant le cyclisme comme mode de transport viable

Encourager un meilleur esprit communautaire :
- en offrant nos ressources aux groupes du campus et de lextrieur du campus
- en appuyant les projets et les vnements en lien avec le vlo
- en collaborant avec dautres organisations cyclistes

In the Media

McGill Daily March 13th "Bike collective gets rolling"

All members of the collective (anyone who would like to get involved) are invited to participate - we would love to hear your input! Minutes from previous meetings are posted below. They might not necessarily be listed below in chronological order, and some are missing (sorry!).

item.title: Collective Call Out
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
Many people replied during out new volunteer orientation that they wanted to be part of the collective. However, we suspect a certain degree of misunderstanding. You are still more than welcome to come test the waters. Not being part of the collective means you can and will volunteer, participate in events, attend workshops, etc. But there are a lot of things you can do as a collective member...

What does it mean to be part of the collective?

Here is more or less what collective members have done in the past:

-bottomline major renovations

-make orders

-pick up old bikes

-organize workshops

-plan volunteer orientations

-shape the general direction of the shop

-have collective/consensus based meetings once a week

-coordinate volunteers

-make a website

-deal with ssmu

-make general and really really specific decisions

-come up with crazy ideas that we cant yet do because of lack of capacity/feasability

-liaison with other student groups

-have many votes on a name (which is currently THE FLAT)

-make way to many to do lists

-make propaganda

-eat a lot of dinners at altaib

Of course the sky is the limit. With your participation we could do much more. We seek people that are willing to commit, put in some time for some general tasks, take on some responsibilities, and are willing to function collectively and consensusly.

Currently our meetings our scheduled for Wednesdays at 6 (but if you cant make that time and still want to be involved (again " theflat.bikecollective@gmail.com).

We are very open to change, but please don't show up promising radical change and unwavering dedication, and then disappear off the face of the earth. It is really hard to get anything done that way.

Anyways if you still want to get involved come to a meeting on January 28 at 6PM in B-02 Shatner (The FLAT). Or send us an email. We love emails (theflat.bikecollective@gmail.co

item.title: Workshops
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
Come learn about bikes at our workshop series! Presently, we do not yet have dates for our planned workshops. Stay tuned near the start of fall semester for workshops and get-togethers!

Past Workshops:

If you're interested in any of these topics, let us know and we can set up a workshop on it! BIKE TUNE-UP 101 This workshop is for those who like riding their bike but have never done repair work themselves. Includes how to do a bike checkup, diagnosing common issues, and addressing problems at home & on the cheap! GENERAL BIKE MAINTENANCE: Checking your brakes, tubes, derailleurs, bearings, all the good basics to brush up on. GEARS Keep those derailleurs shifting smoothly with proper installation, adjustments, and common troubleshooting tips. WHEELS Learn about the workings of wheels, spoke replacement, wheel truing, bearing overhaul, and more. SINGLE-SPEED CONVERSION Get rid of those gears! The ins and outs of transforming your bike into the perfect fixed gear or single speed, including navigating traffic laws with a fixie. WINTERIZING Bike mods, maintenance and general tips to keep you up and running this winter!

Check out our previous workshop handouts:

Handouts: The FLAT on flats The FLAT on brakes The FLAT on derailleurs (Gears) The FLAT on bottom brackets The FLAT on headsets THE FLAT on wheels The FLAT on Winterizing Posters: Fall2015Workshops If your bike needs work, bring it in and we can use it in the hands-on section of the workshop.
*At the FLAT we recognize that bike mechanics and knowledge exchange about bikes can be very intimidating. We also recognize that, like many other bike collectives and shops, we have an over-representation of male mechanics. To address both of these concerns we have devoted certain workshops especially to women and trans folk to help create a space for learning that is non-threatening and encourages involvement of people of all skill levels. We are starting the women and trans workshops to address concerns expressed by many of our users.

item.title: Volunteer Orientation : Wednesday March 18 (7:30PM)
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: A volunteer orientation day, for all those who have and/or would like to volunteer at the flat, will be held on March 18 at 7:30pm at the Flat. We strongly recommend that you attend if you are available during this time so that you can learn about what being a volunteer entails, express your interest in helping out, and meet the people you'll be working with. All persons welcome; no experience necessary. See you all on the big day.

item.title: Volunteer
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
The FLAT Bike Collective is entirely run by volunteers. These include volunteers who help people during shop hours, mechanics, and collective members. The Flat strives to be a welcoming, non-hierarchical, anti-oppressive space open to anyone wanting to work on their bike. We do not fix bikes, we teach people how to fix their own bike. We also offer workshops on specific aspects of bike mechanics.

Interested in Volunteering?

Being a volunteer at the FLAT is an opportunity to gain lots of hands-on experience with bikes. Whether you have a lot, or no experience, everyone has something to offer. If you are just beginning to learn about bikes, we encourage you to attend our workshops (see "workshops," more info will be released in the Fall) and/or ask our more experienced volunteers for training on the basics before your first shift. If you are available to work as a volunteer for any of our shifts (see "hours"), please e-mail our volunteer coordinators with your availability, contact information, and skill-level. No experience necessary! Do you want to help with social media, graphic design, promoting the shop, managing volunteer schedules, or anything that isn't bike-specific? Drop us a line at theflat.bikecollective@gmail.com! We could always use your help.
Volunteer Coordinators can be contacted at: theflat.bikecollective@gmail.com or in our space when we are open.

Interested in being part of the Collective?

The collective meets a few times each semester to coordinate operations. Anyone is welcome to attend and help with the work and decisions that keep the Flat rolling. The meetings are run according to a consensus decision-making process. Please e-mail the Flat (theflat.bikecollective@gmail.com) for info on the next meeting. We will be more likely to respond to any questions or comments you have if you e-mail or message us on Facebook, instead of leaving a comment on our site.

item.title: New Workshop Series
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: Meeting WEDNESDAY JUNE 10 AT 6PM, in the lounge of the Shatner Building on McGill campus (one floor above the shop) for anyone interested in lending a hand, coordinating or teaching in the next workshop series. Without community involvement these workshops are not possible, so come on out. Wanted: Workshop Coordinators Do you have a certain level of expertise on all or some bike components that you'd like share? We need people interested in leading workshops for the summer months. If you've ever attended a workshop at the Flat, you'll know they are always informative as well as friendly and informal. Or, for example, do you know enough about bottom brackets to teach other people if you had a sidekick to back you up? We can arrange for you to teach with someone else too. Please send an e-mail to theflat.bikecollective@gmail.com if you're interested.

item.title: September 2009 Hours
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
Hello Bike Buddies!
The shop hours will continue to be 5:00 PM to 8:00 PM on Mondays, Tuesdays and Thursdays through the month of September, with a couple of exceptions: Monday, the 7th, we are closed for Labour day, and Tuesday, 15th, we will be closed for Activities Night.
Look out for New Volunteer Orientation on Wednesday the 16th of September, and if you want to get involved, you can always send us an e-mail at theflat.bikecollective@gmail.com

item.title: Buying a Used Bike
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
There are so many bikes molding away in people's basements, rusting in alleys and taking up space in non-cyclists homes that it is a wonder that anyone buys a new bike at all. However, buying a used bike can be pretty intimidating. The following guide should help you with choosing your next bike! 1. Decide what kind of bike you want:
Bikes come in many flavors, decide what kind of bike you want before you start looking.
Road Bike: A road bike is the most efficient type of bike. A road bike often has gears (though single speeds and fixed gears are currently also in style), drop handlebars (which look like rams horns) and a straight top tube. You ride a road bike in an 'aggressive' position, with your back almost parallel to the road which can be uncomfortable for some people, however this is more aerodynamic, so if speed is your goal, this is for you!
Mixte/ step-through frame (often erroneously referred to as a 'ladies' frame): these are very quick to mount, as you don't have to step over the top tube and are great for people with restricted agility. They can be a little heavier, but can be safer as they are easier to step off. Great if you wear loose clothing (e.g. skirts)
Single speed: Means you only have one gear, which can make it hard to get up hill, get started from a stop, or to get to higher speed when going down hill. However, you don't need a derailleur (the part which allows you to change gears) which is one of the parts of a bike which is likely to break, especially in winter.
Fixed Gear: a fixed gear bike cannot coast, so you have to pedal at all times when the bike is moving. As there are fewer moving parts, they supposedly require less maintenance. When going down steep inclines, you need to pedal extremely fast. Don't buy a fixed gear bike before having ridden one, as they require a very different riding style. These might be a little more expensive than their geared or single-speed cousins as your bike will also come with some 'hipster-cool'.
Mountain Bike: Designed for off-road cycling, these have much larger tires (which increase rolling resistance on the road, decreasing your efficiency). Mountain bikes often have a less aggressive and more upright riding position, and are very comfortable on bumpy montreal roads. Suspension can add some comfort, but at the price of added weight and more moving parts that can seize in the winter.
Utility Bike / City bike: These are designed for practical transportation over speed or weight issues. Parts are often stronger, and more durable and feature an upright riding position.
Materials
Bikes are made of many different materials, each of which have pros and cons.
Steel: What most older bikes are made of. Steel can be a little heavier, however is more flexible and gives a more comfortable ride.
Aluminium: What a lot of newer bikes are made of. They often have larger tubes and are sometimes lighter than their steel counterparts.
Carbon: Expensive bikes are made of carbon fibre. Not recommended for a first-time-buy, or a get-around-town bike.
Bamboo: Oh yeah! http://www.calfeedesign.com/bamboo.htm
2. Price range / How much time you want to spend fixing it.
When buying a used bike you often have to make a trade off on how much time you want to spend fixing the bike and how much money you want to spend. You can find bikes for free in the garbage, but these will require a lot more work to get into working condition. A good used bike should set you back around $80-150, but this varies with the time of year, the type of bike and the condition. Set your price range before you start looking for a bike, and it will be easier to say no to a bike which seems too expensive.
3. Start Looking!
Ask your friends if they have any bikes which they don't need, look for a good deal on moving days, check in dumpsters or... look online at the following links:
Craigslist
Kijiji
Lespac
Use your discretion and common sense when looking at online postings. There are a lot of stolen bikes which are sold online, and a lot of people who are trying to make a quick buck on crappy bikes. However, there are also a lot of legitimate postings!
Some things you want to look for:
Bikes with the brand / decals still visible: Bike thieves will often paint bikes so that they are no longer recognizable by their rightful owners.
A description of the size, type, condition and material of the bike.
Sometimes a 'reason for sale' is good piece-of-mind
If the posting is in French, do your best to reply in French, the poster will appreciate it, and will be more likely to get back to you.
4. Go see the bike!
Once you have identified a bike which fits your criteria, go see it! Remember, by going to see the bike never commits you to actually buying it, and there are some basic things that you want to check before you lay down your cash:
0. Size / Seatpost.
Make sure the bike fits you. Sit on it. A little bit of discomfort can quickly become a lot of discomfort if you are riding for a long time.
Check to see if you can move the seatpost, if it is at the wrong height and you can't move it because it is rusted in place, consider passing the bike up. Stuck seatposts can often be really hard to unstick.
1. Frame (Rust + dents etc) + Fork (straight)
The frame is the hardest part to fix. Check for any damage from crashes: dings, cracks or bent parts (which don't look like they should be bent). On a steel frame, small dents are OK, while on aluminium frames, dents can lead to fracture. On a steel frame, check for rust. Some surface rust is OK, but excessive rust can mean that the bike has not been treated too well in the past, which can lead to a lot more maintenance for you.
Look at the fork, and make sure that they are parallel. On steel forks, it is possible to bend them back (a little!), but not on aluminium forks. Make sure the fork doesn't move forwards and backwards in the frame, if it does, the headset needs tightening (come to The Flat, and we will show you how!).
Buying a frame with problems is not a good idea.
2. Bottom Bracket (the part which connects the cranks together).
Grab both cranks (the part the pedals are attached to) and try and move them from side to side. There should be no play. If there is, you will need to tighten the bottom bracket.
3. Wheels (true) + tires
Lift the bike off the ground and spin the wheels. When looking at them from behind, the wheels should be round. Compare the rim of the wheel to a fixed point on the bike (e.g. the brakes) and see whether there are points in the rim which are closer or further away. If there are, it means the wheel is out of 'true' and can effect the efficacy of the brakes.
Check the wear on the tires. If there are frayed parts, or if the thread is extremely worn, you will need a new set.
4. Brakes
Check that the brakes are able to stop the bike! Sometimes they just need minor adjustments, but sometimes brakes can be rusted in place. Check that the brake cables and housing (the plastic sheath around the cables) are not rusty or frayed. If they are, you should change them.
5. Gears / drivetrain.
Check that the cables that go to the gear shifters aren't rusty. Check for rust on the chain. When pedalling, make sure that the chain doesn't 'skip' at any point, if it does your chain might have a bad link. A chain that sags too much is worn, and will need to be replaced. If the bike you are looking at has gears, check that both the front and back shift smoothly and into all of the gears.
6. Take the bike for a test ride.
You will often find more problems by riding a bike than simply inspecting it. If at anytime you don't feel safe, stop riding. Make sure you take note of any problems, as these will be good bargaining points with the vendor.
5. Come see us!
If you have just bought a used bike you should get it checked out by a professional mechanic, or come to The Flat when we are open and we can help you do a safety check. Feel free to come talk to any of our volunteer mechanics before you buy a bike and ask them about any of the checks mentioned above.
6. Ride!
and Enjoy!

item.title: Bike Sales!
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
If you are looking for a new used bike, come talk to us (see below)! Alternatively, one of our volunteers wrote this guide going over the basics of how to choose one and where to buy a while ago: Buying a Used Bike.

Buying a bike from the Flat:

There are two ways to get a bike from the FLAT:

1. Refitted Bikes!

We build and sell ready-to-ride bikes on occasion, depending on volunteer availability and time. We source parts from donated or junk bikes in our storage and build something new and beautiful. Keep an eye out on our social media during the fall and spring months for our bikes for sale!

Our prices typically range from 50-100$ with exceptions.

Since our priority is always to get more people on bikes, you can request discretionary funding up to 100$ on a bike purchase. Please contact us via email (theflat.bikecollective@gmail.com) for more information.

Please note that we do not build custom bikes upon request.

2. Project Bikes!

We have a large stock of bike frames and parts in our storage space. You are more than welcome to pick through the pile and purchase project bikes from us for a very decent price (less than a completed bike).

After that, it's yours to keep! Usually, abandoned bikes need some love before becoming road-safe again, some more so than others. But there must be a place you can learn all about to fixing and repairing bikes for free... How about THE FLAT!

There are a few things to note when purchasing a project bike:

  1. The Flat is a DIY bike repair space. You are welcome to build a bike from our stock using our workshop space and tools, but know that the volunteers cannot build the bike for you. If you're just looking to get your hands dirty and learn about bikes, consider becoming a volunteer (no experience req'd) or attend one of our workshops!
  2. If you are building a bike in our workshop, please speak with a volunteer to make sure that you have all the right parts before starting. Too often does someone start a project at the Flat only to abandon it a few weeks later!
  3. Unfortunately, due to limited space availability, you can no longer store your bike or project in our storage area. You can either lock it on campus or bring it home with you. Volunteers are allowed to store up to one project bike in the storage area.

FAQ:

Where do you get your bikes?

Short answer: donations and abandoned bikes on campus.
Long answer: First, when its time for cleaning... The FLAT volunteers are handed by a whole lots of zip ties and paper tags by McGill Facility Services, and we go out and tag the slowing rusting bikes on campus. In a few weeks our friends at the Facility go out and cut the locks and stores them in a safe place, and in a few months all the unpicked up bikes are moved to the SSMU basement under the management of the FLAT. See the pic above! (will add pic later..)

How much does it cost?

Most bikes go between $50 and $100. Two volunteers will take a look at the said bike and each proposes a price. The average will be the final price. In case of refitted bikes, we add the cost of the replacement parts. We will prioritize used/salvaged parts we have on hand.

When can I get one?

A project bike? TODAY! (If we're open, that is..) A refitted one? It may take a while...

Past builds

Here are some bikes built by our volunteers in the past few years (already sold):

item.title: Vlo! Vlo! Montreal Bike Co-Op Conference
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: From September 24th - 26th there will be a bike co-op conference held here in Montreal located at UQAM. It will be a great opportunity to get to know the greater bike co-op community (there will be people from all 7 of montreal's bike co-ops as well as other community bike organizations), attend interesting workshops (ie: smashing bikes back to life, how to run a bike shop, anti-oppression, working with immigrants, 3-speed hubs, winter biking, summary of united bicycle institute lessons on modern bike repair, etc ...), and have some fun (musical bike performance, food served, party saturday night, and more ...). All volunteers and bikey folks are encouraged to attend. For more information and to register for the conference go to http://velovelo.ca/

item.title: Winter Riding Workshop, Wednesday December 14th!!
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: Winter's (supposedly) a-comin'! Don't worry though, The Flat, in collaboration with Le Petit Velo Rouge is here to help you keep your bike (and yourself) on the road! There will be a winter riding workshop this coming wednesday, where you will learn all about how to dress, how to ride, and how to keep your bike in tip-top shape during the salty season. The important stuff: When: Wednesday December 14th, 19:00 - 21:00 Where: The Flat Bike Collective, 3480 Rue McTavish, Room B02 For: Everyone! Cost: PWYC ($5 suggested donation to LPVR) Who: Le Petit Velo Rouge, Cam from CycleBird couriers will also be present to recount his experiences riding 8 hours a day through the winter! RSVP: internal.lpvr@gmail.com (or just show up) More info: As part of our winter mechanics workshop series, Le Petit Velo Rouge and The Flat are holding a Winter Riding workshop on December 14th, 7-9pm. Check out our winter riding zine (http://faridrener.files.wordpress.com/2011/09/winter-riding-zine-v2-1.pdf), ahead of time to know what we will be talking about! Please RSVP as space is limited: internal.lpvr@gmail.com Why ride in the winter? Riding in the winter is fun! We see it as the most practical winter sport once you get used to how your bike handles in the diff erent types of snow, you will find it is the only comfortable way to get around. Surprisingly, riding in winter tends to be warmer than walking or taking public transport. Since you are moving your body so much, you end up generating your own heat. Standing around waiting for the bus is a sure-fi re way of getting cold and miserable, and stepping off the over-heated metro with your full winter-penguinoutfi t is a great way for your sweat to keep you nice and frosty. On your bike, you take advantage of the crisp air that the winter provides lungfulls of that will easily lift you out of those winter blues. The best part of riding in the winter is the way it peaks all of your senses. Riding at night, right after a powdery snowfall when all the cars are safely tucked away in their garages, there is an intense silence. Th e only thing you hear is the snow getting crushed under your tires, a noise you will come to crave during the muggy summer. This noise vibrates through your whole body, and even though you are almost fl oating over the road, you feel completely connected to it. You will start learning the diff erent types of snow and ice, and the way they change how your bike feels under you. You will realize how diff erent cars smell in the winter their engines straining against the cold (but you only get stronger as the winter gets colder!). You will taste the salt, that awful stuff that will destroy your humble steed if you arent careful http://lepetitvelorouge.wordpress.com/2011/12/01/winter-riding-workshop/

item.title: Winter 2012 Workshop Series
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: This winter Le Petit Vlo Rouge (LPVR) has taken on the task of organizing our workshop series. All workshops will take place at the Flat, however a suggested pay-what-you-can donation of $5 towards starting up LPVR's new space is encouraged. Workshops are open to everyone. All workshops take place on Wednesdays from 7pm til 9pm. January 11th: Bicycle Basics Fixing flat tires, regular bike maintenance, how to use tools; (Using wrenches, screwdrives, etc. so you dont injure yourself or your tools!) January 18th: Brakes Everything and anything to make sure you can stop! January 25th: Ball Bearing systems Headsets, Hubs and 3-piece bottom brackets. February 1st: Gears Getting your mechanical advantage just right! February 8th: Wheels Truing, adjusting hubs, cleaning rims, building basics. February 15th: Advanced topics Big tools; weird parts; compatibilities; the answer to life, theuniverse, and everything. How hammers will fix everything. Please RSVP! Space is limited! internal.lpvr@gmail.com

item.title: Spring is (almost) here
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: Soon enough (we hope) spring will be here. For us at the Flat that means that there will be tons of people wanting to get their bikes ready for the new season. If you're one of those people you might want to consider beating the spring rush and coming to the shop rather sooner than later. Recently it has been pretty quiet during shifts and our volunteers will be able to devote their almost undivided attention to all of your bike questions and problems. As always, the shop is open Monday, Tuesday, and Thursday from 5 to 7:30 pm. See you at the shop! item.title: Wheel workshops at Right to Move
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
Our friends from Right to Move/La Voie Libre at Concordia will host two workshops about wheels on March 25 and April 1. The workshops will be held at Right to Move. Please RVSP to righttomove@gmail.com
We will be holding a truing workshop on Sunday, the 25th of March, and a wheel-building workshop on Sunday, the 1st of April. Both workshops will commence at 11:00AM, and go until approximately 1:30PM. The cost for each workshop will be $5.00. Those coming to either workshop, and especially the wheel-building workshop are suggested to have at least a base knowledge of wheels and wheel-truing. As well, those wishing to attend the wheel-building workshop are strongly encouraged to attend the truing workshop to ensure that everybody's on the same page. Due to limited resources, the number of people who can attend either workshop will be capped at 12. As such, anyone interested in attending either should rsvp as early as possible. Looking forward to seeing you there. -- Right to Move/La voie libre http://www.rtm-lvl.org/ Schedule:http://www.rtm-lvl.org/phpicalendar/week.php Tel:514-999-4885 mail: c/o QPIRG-Concordia 1500 de Maisonneuve o., Suite 204, Montral, QC, Canada H3G 1N1

item.title: "Girl's Night In" at Right to Move
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
Excellent news from our friends at Right to Move:
Right to Movenowopen its doors every last Saturday of the month from 6 to 9 pm to welcome people who identify as female or transgender. In an open and safe environment, you are invited to come work on your bike with the help of our experienced volunteers. At Right to Move, we try our best to facilitate an inclusive and empowering environment that is friendly and safe for all community members. However, we realize that sexism and gender discrimination are strong forces that effect women and trans people in their everyday lives and can also be present during general shop hours at Right to Move. And so, during the Girls Night In, all volunteers will be female and/or transgender. So come enjoy an early Saturday night with us and pimp your bike before hitting the bars. All female and trans identified people welcome! More info on our website:http://girlsnightinrtm.wordpress.com/ And on facebook:facebook.com/GirlsNightInRTM // Au plaisir de se voir samedi! La voie libreouvre maintenant ses portes chaque dernier samedi du mois de 18 21h pour accueillir toutes les personnes sidentifiant comme femme ou transgenre. Dans un environnement ouvert et scuritaire, nos bnvoles exprimentes vous aideront rparer votre bicyclette. La voie libre, nous faisons de notre mieux pour crer un environnement inclusif et stimulant qui est amical et scuritaire pour tous-toutes les membres de la communaut. Nous ralisons par ailleurs que le sexisme et la discrimination entre les sexes sont une ralit pour la majorit des femmes et trans dans leur vie quotidienne et qui peuvent mme tre prsentes durant les heures douvertures normales. Cest pourquoi les bnvoles du Girls Night In sont toutes femmes et/ou transgenre. Vous tes donc invites commencer votre samedi soir en beaut et prparer votre vlo pour une longue nuit de fte! Toutes les personnes sidentifiant comme femmes et transgenre sont les bienvenues! Toutes les informations se retrouvent sur notre site web:http://girlsnightinrtm.wordpress.com/ Et sur facebook:facebook.com/GirlsNightInRTM

item.title: Women and Trans Folk--Queer Night at the Flat, May 9th!
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
Women and Trans Folk * * Femmes et personnes trans

Queer Night at the Flat * * soire queer au Flat

Every 2nd Wednesday of the Month * * le deuxime mercredi du mois

Starting May 9th * * commenant le 9 mai

5.00-7.30 * * 17h 19h30

(**Le franais suit l'anglais**) The Flat now hosts WTF night, for people identified as women and/or trans, on the second Wednesday of every month. While The Flat's goal is to always be a welcoming and positive environment for fixing bikes and learning about bike mechanics, sexism, gender discrimination, and patriarchal BS can still happen. WTF night is about trying to eliminate(challenge?) those dynamics and about empowering more people to learn bike repair and use The Flat's space, tools, and resources to their advantage. That said, trans folk and women are also encouraged to work on their bikes at the Flat during regular hours. WE NEED VOLUNTEERS to help! If you have a bit (or a lot) of bike mechanic experience or want to learn from experience, let us know. e-mail us at theflat.bikecollective@gmail.com with WTF in the subject line. ************************************************************************************************************* L'atelier de vlo, The Flat, situ sur le campus McGill, organise maintenant sa soire FPT (pour Femmes et Personnes Trans) le deuxime mercredi de chaque mois. Bien que l'objectif de l'atelier a toujours t d'tre accueillant et accessible toutes et tous, le sexisme et la discrimination rgnent toujours dans notre socit, et surtout dans les ateliers de vlo--espaces souvent domins par le machisme. La soire FPT cherche dmanteler ces systmes d'ingalits, et donc invite les personnes s'identifiant comme femmes ou trans utiliser l'atelier, les outils, et toutes les autres ressources disponibles. Cela dit, toutes personnes s'identifiant comme femmes ou trans sont toujours encourages travailler sur leurs vlos pendant les heures rgulires de l'atelier (Lun, Mar, Jeu de 17h-19h30)! **NOUS AVONS BESOIN DE BNVOLES!** Si tu as un peu (ou beaucoup!) d'exprience en mcanique de vlo, ou aimerais apprendre, fait le nous savoir! Envoyez-nous un courriel theflat.bikecollective@gmail.com, avec comme object ''FPT\WTF''

item.title: Spring Workshops!
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
After a very long hiatus, the Flat is again offering workshops! Note the schedule change: Wednesday, 23 May: 5 - 6.30 How to Fix a Flat 7 - 8:30 All You Ever Wanted to Know About Brakes (and then some)

How to fix a flat

Fixing a flat is the most common problem cyclists encounter, but it is not necessarily the most straight-forward! We'll start from the beginning and cover removing your wheel, patching, tube sizes, tire pressure, and plenty more.

All you ever wanted to know about brakes (and then some)

We will cover the various kinds of brakes, brake pads, and cables and housing. Everyone is welcome to attend, and there is no need to reserve a spot. Workshops are, as always, free to attend. We will announce future workshops as they are scheduled. Is there a workshop you would like to see offered? Email us at theflat.bikecollective@gmail.com

item.title: June at the Flat
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: New Hours The SSMU building now closes at 8pm, so the Flat will be closing at 7.30. Our goal is to continue to be open Monday, Tuesday and Thursday, however, our schedule is dependent on volunteers. We will post any closures here. Unfortunately, the building will be closing at 6pm during July and August, so the Flat will not be able to operate our regular evening shifts. We will be trying out day shifts (2-6pm) in July. Volunteer! Know a little about bikes? Know a lot? Don't know a thing? We need volunteers of all sorts, so consider volunteering! You can Email us! If you are hesitant, come visit us at the shop and introduce yourself. Wednesdays at the Flat Wednesdays we host a variety of events at the Flat. Collective Meeting: 6 June, 2012 The first Wednesday of the month is our Collective Meeting. Everyone is welcome to participate. Meetings start at 5.30 at the Flat. Women, Trans, and Queer Night: 13 June, 2012 The second Wednesday of the month is our WTQ Night. We are open for women, trans and queer folk to work on their bikes. We are also looking for volunteers to help out! Tasquerade: 20 June, 2012 The third Wednesday of the month is our Tasquerade. We spend a few hours tidying the shop, organising donations, general maintenance of the space as well as great music and pizza. Never volunteered with the Flat? It is a great way to get to know both the space and the other volunteers. Workshops: 27 June, 2012 The fourth Wednesday of the month we reserve for workshops. The workshop is still TBA for June--stayposted! In the works We are in the process of scheduling regular bike builds. We are also in the process of scheduling a wheelbuilding class. Interested in either? Email us. Volunteers Did we forget to mention we needed volunteers? We need volunteers! Come on out!

item.title: Rez Project looking for workshop facilitators
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
FYI...
Volunteer Call Out for Rez Project Facilitators
Rez Project is looking for volunteers to co-facilitate workshops on Sexual Assault, Gender and Sexuality given to first-year students living in residences at McGill in September. Rez Project is an initiative that began eight years ago by SACOMSS, Queer McGill, and Trans*/Gender Alliance to increase education and start discussion on these complex subjects at the beginning of the year to make McGill a more accepting and safe(r) place. The workshops are held in the evenings throughout September, Monday-Thurs
day. Your participation, as much or as little as you can, is extremely valuable. Note that facilitators must take part in half-day facilitation trainings that happen Sept 1 and 2 OR Sept 8 and 9. (Meals will be provided). For more information // to be connected with past years facilitators // to sign up as a facilitator, email us at rezproject2012@gmail.com

item.title: Campus Crops is hosting a film-and-crafts pot-luck evening
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
FYI: Campus Cropsis hosting anfreeevening of craft and film-watching fun times,Sunday August 19th @ 7:30pm! To start off, we'll be making some artsyplant signs(all materials will be provided). You can help us make some for our garden or make some for your own plants at home! Afterwards, we're going to be screeningThe Global Banquet: Politics of Foodin our garden. The documentary "explores the politics that threaten global food security, and demonstrates the destructive aspects of the corporate globalization of food" (clickherefor more info on the film). Also, we'll have somehome-made vegan pizzafor you to snack on, made with some of our garden-fresh veg! (Potluck items would also be greatly appreciated!) Everyone is welcome!Feel free to drop by whenever - for one or both activities! When: Sunday, August 19th Sign-Making @ 7:30pm Film Screening @ 9pm (film is approx. 50mins.) Where:Garden behind 3534 University St. (*back-up rain location TBA*)
Cost:FREE!Potluck items appreciated!
Hope to see you there!

item.title: Workshop: Get ready for winter! October 24
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="500"] Photo by Andreas.
This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 2.0 Generic License.[/caption]It's sad, but there's nothing we can do to stop it: winter is coming. Are you thinking about riding your bike through the winter but don't really know if it's feasible? Are you looking for advice on how to winterize your ride and yourself? If your answer is "yes," you should come to our workshop/info session at The Flat on Wednesday, October 24 at 7pm. Krzysztof and Harald will share their experiences with riding year-round, offer advice, and answer your questions. As always, the workshop is free and open to anyone. item.title: Interested in becoming a volunteer? New volunteer orientation on Nov 21
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: Are you interested in volunteering at the Flat? Or you already are a volunteer but haven't done the mandatory orientation workshop yet? Then you should come to this month's volunteer orientation at the Flat on Wednesday, November 21 from 4 to 5 pm. Luz and Harald will tell you all you ever wanted to know about the inner workings of your favorite community bike shop and why volunteering there is great fun. After the workshop you can also hang around for our "taskerade", i.e. the monthly clean-up-and-eat-pizza gathering which will give you a chance to meet more volunteers. item.content:encoded: Les soires pour femmes, personnes trans et/ou queers sont le deuxime mercredi du mois. Au Flat, on sait que tout le monde n'est pas l'aise dans un atelier de rparation de vlo. Donc, on a une soire qui vise aider les gens devenir plus confortable dans l'atelier. Venez au Flat le 14 novembre de 17h 19h30, et on vous enseignera comment rparer votre vlo. At the Flat, we try to create a less oppressive space. We wish everyone was comfortable in a bike shop, but it just ain't true. If you are female, trans and/or queer and don't feel comfortable coming into the shop on regular nights, come by for our WTQF night. We'll show you how to fix your bike so that you feel more comfortable using the space during our regular open hours. If you'd like to volunteer please e-mail us at theflat.bikecollective@gmail.com or just come on by!

item.title: Wheel building workshop, December 7
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
[caption id="" align="alignnone" width="500"] Photo by Paul Watson. License: Creative Commons BY-NC-SA[/caption] The Flat will be hosting a wheelbuilding workshop, run by Stewart, on December 7. The session will go through:
  • Rim, hub and spoke types, selection and measurements
  • Lacing thewheel(3-cross) if applicable
  • Tensioning and dishing
If you don't already have the parts to build up a wheel, there will be an affordable package for a front wheel available. It includes a Shimano 32 hole hub, 32 stainless spokes and nipples, and a double-wall aluminum Weinmann rim, and costs $35. There will be only 4 spots so available -- so if you're interested you should email us ASAP (please also mention if you want the build kit or if you'll bring your own materials). The workshop will take place at the Flat on the evening of Friday, December 7. If there is a lot of interest, there might be a second workshop in January. Oh, and best things last: the workshop is free!

item.title: Bike touring and MYOG workshop March 1
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: Spring is still some time away, but now is a good time to plan for your awesome summer bike tours and to make your own camping equipment. To help you out with this, the Flat will be hosting two workshops on March 1. [caption id="" align="alignnone" width="509"] Penny stove in action[/caption] 1. Making your own camping alcohol stove: Harald will show how to make a very efficient and lightweight out of soda cans. This is a hands-on workshop and at the end of it you will have your own soda can stove. The number of participants is limited and there are very few spots left. Time for this is Friday, March 1, 17:30 at the Flat. If you're interested, please send an email to kliems@gmail.com. First come, first serve. Cost for the workshop is 5 dollars to cover the Flat's expenses. 2. Touring get together/skill share: Some of us already have been bike touring and some of us would like to -- so let's get together and share experiences, advice, and in general have a good time. Bring your favorite piece of touring gear, maps, photos, whatever. The get-together will happen right after the workshop, i.e. Friday, March 1, 19:00. Number of participants is not limited and the event is free, but please nonetheless RSVP to kliems@gmail.com and let me know if you have any prior bike touring experience.

item.title: Report from the MYOG and bike touring workshops
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: Two weeks ago we had two bike touring related workshops, one to build your own ultra-light camp stove out of soda cans, and one general bike touring get-together. The stove building workshop was fully booked out, and we're sorry if you couldn't get a spot. However, building the stoves is not that difficult and doesn't require many tools. So if you couldn't come to the workshop you should check out these very detailed instructions by Mark Jurey, the inventor of the design. [caption id="attachment_985" align="alignnone" width="524"] The tedious process of slowly cutting off the soda cans[/caption] In the end everyone at the workshop was able to finish at least the main part of the stove and some people have s tested it. After the workshop a few of us got together and talked about plans for bike touring this year. Many questions were asked and answered, we looked at maps, and discussed about the many different ways of bike touring -- from several month-long fully self-supported tours to short overnight trips close to where you live. If you're interested in touring, feel free to stop by at the Flat, as we have some books, maps, and, of course, knowledgable volunteers.

item.title: Montreal Urban Cycling Week / Semaine du vlo urbain 2013/05/13-18
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
The Coalition Vlo Montral/Montreal Bike Coalition is a newly founded group to help improve urban cycling in the Greater Montreal area. One of their first larger activities will be a week of discussions, themed rides, and other events to bring together the many Montreal groups and citizens that are interested in making Montreal an even better place to get around by bike. Below is their call for proposals:
How can we collectively create the conditions to make urban cycling flourish in Greater Montreal ? The Montreal Bike Coalition invites you to propose activities for May 13th to 17th, 2013 which engage with this question. This series of events is part of the Coalitions launch, and will inform the first edition of the Montreal Urban Cycling Summit, which istaking place on Saturday May 18th, 2013.The Summit is open to anyone, and has the goal of summing up the weeks discussions and developing them into an action plan to support the growth of urban cycling in Greater Montreal. Send us your proposition!
  • The proposed activities must take part during the week of May 13th to 17th, 2013 and be organized by the groups themselves, though the Coalition will provide support to and promotion for organizers.
  • The call is open to all individuals and organizations within the Montreal region.
  • There are no restrictions on the type of activities that can be proposed: conferences, public debates, panel discussions, workshops, movie projections, cycling infrastructure visits, themed rides let your imagination roll!
  • The proposals must be short and simple (300 words maximum).
  • Some events may be selected for reportingbased on their capacity to engage with the question of the Summit:How can we collectively create the conditions to make urban cycling flourish in Greater Montreal ?
Please send your activitys proposal and any questions toinfo@coalitionvelomontreal.org.

DEADLINE FOR PROPOSALS: APRIL 5th2013

Comment crer ensemble les conditions afin que le vlo urbain fleurisse dans le Grand Montral? La Coalition vlo de Montral invite la communaut proposer des activits labores autour de cette question du 13 au 17 mai 2013. Cette srie dvnements sinscrit dans le cadre du lancement de la Coalition, et servira de base la premire dition du Sommet du vlo urbain de Montral qui se tiendra le 18 mai 2013. Le Sommet a pour but de faire la synthse des changes de la semaine et proposer un plan daction pour le dveloppement du vlo urbain dans le Grand Montral. Envoyez-nous votre proposition!
  • Les activits proposes doivent avoir lieu dans la semaine du 13 au 17 mai 2013 et tre produites de manire autonome par les organisations, alors que la Coalition fournira du soutien aux organisateurs et de la promotion pour mener bien vos vnements.
  • Lappel est ouvert tous les individus et groupes de la rgion montralaise.
  • Il ny a aucune restriction sur le type dactivits pouvant tre proposes: confrences, dbats publics, panels de discussion, ateliers, projections de films, visites dinfrastructures cyclables, balades thmatiques laissez rouler votre imagination!
  • Les propositions doivent tre simples et courtes (maximum 300 mots).
  • Certains vnements pourront tre mandats deffectuer un rapport en fonction de leur capacit susciter des changes sur la question du Sommet: Comment crer ensemble les conditions afin que le vlo urbain fleurisse dans le Grand Montral?
Veuillez envoyer votre proposition et toute question info@coalitionvelomontreal.org. DATE LIMITE DES PROPOSITIONS : 5 AVRIL 2013

item.title: taskerade tomorrow 2-4pm
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
Hey flatters/flat friends/flat enthusiasts!
Tomorrow is the third wednesday of May and you know what that means... TASKERADE!!!
Come on out and help us organize and clean up the shop! There will be tasty treats, good tunes, and a whole lot of sorting + (re)arranging fun!
If you're new to the space it's a great way to get to know the shop and meet and hang out with volunteers. If you're new to bikes, it's a great way to get to know the parts that make up a bike and the tools that go into fixing them. If you've been around a while and/or know a lot about bikes its a great way to help people who are newer to these things learn about them.
Hope to see you there!

item.title: -----September at the flat!-----
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
Happy September everybody!

Here's what's happening at the flat this month.
(point form then details below):

- fall means back to evening hours! 5-7:30pm
- wt*q shift wednesday sept 10th, 5-7:30pm
- volunteer orientation friday sept 12 (plz RSVP)
- we need volunteers!
Change in hours
We're back to evening hours! Yay! That makes our regular opening times 5-7:30pm monday, tuesday and thursday nights. We're still short on volunteers so there may be the possibility of some shop closures, but we'll try to keep you updated.

Women/Trans/Queer Wednesday Sept 10 5-7:30pm
At the Flat, we try to create a less oppressive space. We wish everyone was comfortable in a bike shop, but it just aint true. If you are female, trans and/or queer and dont feel comfortable coming into the shop on regular nights, come by for our WT*Q night.

Volunteer Orientation Friday Sept 12 5pm
Interested in helping out at the shop? Wanna learn about working on bikes? Maybe you'd like to meet and hang with some awesome bike nerds? There are many ways to help, even if you don't know a thing about bikes! Come volunteer with us! We'll be having an orientation this friday to introduce you to the shop and give you an idea of how we work. Please send and email to theflat.bikecollective@gmail.com to RSVP.

We need volunteers!
Speaking of volunteers... Yep, we need your help! We've had to close the shop a few times recently for lack of volunteers. Sadness. Anywhooo... There are many ways to help. Regular shifting (helping people learn about their bikes during our open hours), Helping with organization and clean up of the shop, coordinating volunteers, making bike learning oriented posters, helping work on our zine, helping pick up donations... All kinds of stuff really! Send us an email and/or come to our volunteer orientation on the 12th

That's all for now.. Hope so see you around the shop soon!
p.s. If anybody out there would be into helping with some translation english to french that'd be super nice. Send us an email.

item.title: WT*Q Night tonight!
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
We wish it weren't true, but there are environments where women, trans* or queer people don't feel welcome. Bike shops can be one of them! We open specially on the 2nd Wednesday of every month for a WT*Q night as an attempt to help address this.
We welcome everyone identifying as female, trans*, and/or queer for a night of bike fixing and good jams, in a supportive + positive environment. Come wrench on bikes with like-minded people, leave with community and a smooth ride.

item.title: NOVEMBER AT THE FLAT!
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: October is gone. And with it are the last of the leaves that fell on you and your bike while you were biking along the tree lined streets of beautiful Montral. The crowds are dwindling on the bike paths but not here at the flat. Here we ride strong. Here we ride all year long. (Well, some of us) Things are still pretty hoppin in the shop. Events this month start with a wheel workshop Wednesday Nov 5th. Wheel working Wednesday wheelcall it. (haha, sorry had to) Come learn about all of the parts of the wheel and how everything works together to get you rolling. Bring your own wheel or use one of the many fixer-upper wheels we have kickin around the shop. The workshop will start at 5pm, and run till 7:30. Next up is WT*Q night Wednesday November 12 (5-7:30pm). We welcome everyone identifying as female, trans*, and/or queer for a night of bike fixing and good jams, in a supportive + positive environment. Come wrench on bikes with like-minded people, leave with community and a smooth ride. Rumor around town is WINTER IS COMING. On account of this yearly phenomenon weve decided to have a workshop with all kinds of tips on making thru Montralwinters on your bike. Come one, come all! Learn and share your tips on winter biking Friday November 21 5-6pm. That's all for now. Happy riding everyone,and hope to see you around the shop! PS. Were still looking for volunteers. If you want to get involved send us an email and we'llhook you up. This winter well be building up the bikes in the basement! Come and join us. All skill levels welcome! Its a great way to learn about bikes!

item.title: This weeks events! (Taskerade, Winter biking wksp, bike repurposart)
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
Hope you're enjoying these first few days of snow. Hold on to your hats, and put your pied to the pedals, because just because it's snowing doesn't mean things are going to slow down around here.
So this week is actually pretty active at the flat. We have plans, we have workshops, we'll have pizza and we'll have fun. Everyone's welcome!
Tomorrow (19th - Wednesday) we'll have Taskerade! That's when we all (ALL you hear) come together to the flat and clean up the place and get things organised. We'll have some food and good music, so please drop by at or after 5 pm to help us out. Yay to getting things done!
On Friday (21st) 5-6 pm, we'll have a winter biking workshop. It'll be a very basic explanation of what's helpful when biking when even cars are afraid to venture out. If you have things to ask or to say about pedaling when the snow is pedal high, please drop by. Space will be limited to 15, first come style.
On friday again, 6 to 7:30, we'll have a bike art fiesta. This will be a very casual discussion and planning about repurposing some old bike pieces into objects of art. If you have any ideas, experience, interest or some true inner calling, you're wanted.
Again, everyone's welcome. talk to us if you have any specific questions. hope to see you there!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Hey, that's a clever way of thikinng about it.

item.title: Workshop on Gears
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: We're giving a free workshop on gears and derailleurs! It's this Wednesday, June 3, 2015 from 4:30pm to 6:00pm, at the Flat. All are welcome, but spots are first come first serve by RSVP to theflat.bikecollective@gmail.com.

item.title: WT*Q Night
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
This Wednesday June 10, 2:30-5pm, is Women, Trans* and Queer Night at the Flat!
On this one Wednesday a month, we open specially for self-identified women, trans* and/or queer folk to fix bikes with similarly identified volunteers in a supportive and non-judgmental environment.

item.title: WTQ this Wednesday

item.content:encoded: Wednesday, July 15 2015, 2:30-5:00pm, we open specially for woman, trans* and/or queer-identifying folks. Come on out and fix your bikes with similarly-identified volunteers!

item.title: Change of hours
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: Back to school means back to our regular hours! Starting Monday, August 31, we'll be open 5-7:30pm on Mondays, Tuesdays and Thursdays.

item.title: September at the Flat
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: Back to regular hours (5-7:30pm) monday, tuesday, thursday starting aug 31. Friday Sept 4, 5-8pm - Taskerade Come out and help us prep for this season of bike fixin'! There will be pizza and music and tasty vegan treats! CLOSED Monday Sept 7th (Labour day) CLOSED Tuesday Sept 8th (SSMU Activities night) CLOSED Wednesday Sept 9th (SSMU Activities Night) Wednesday Sept 16th, 5-7:30pm - WT*Q Night WT*Q night is an evening where we open specially for woman, trans* and/or queer-identifying folks. Come on out and fix your bikes with similarly-identified volunteers! Friday Sept 18th, 5-7:30pm - Taskerade! September shop organization part 2. Come out and help us continue our organizing and prep for this season of bike fixin'! Wednesday Sept 23rd, 5-7:30pm - Gears workshop Keep those derailleurs shifting smoothly with proper installation, large and fine adjustments, and common troubleshooting tips. Space is limited, please RSVP theflat.bikecollective@gmail.com to sign up. Friday Sept 25th, 5-6pm Volunteer Orientation Interested in helping out at the shop? Wanna learn about working on bikes? Maybe youd like to meet and hang with some awesome bike nerds? There are many ways to help, even if you dont know a thing about bikes! Come volunteer with us! Well be having an orientation friday Sept 25th to introduce you to the shop and give you an idea of how we work. Please RSVP by sending an email to: theflat.bikecollective@gmail.com

item.title: november events at the flat
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
Hey folks,
Besides our regular opening hours that allow you to fix your bike for free or teach others how to fix their bikes, the Flat is putting on some special events this month that may interest you:
WT*Q Night
Wednesday Nov 11 - 5-7:30pm
We open specially this Wednesday for female, trans*, and/or queer-identifying folk to fix their bikes with similarly-identified volunteers.
Single Speed Conversion Workshop
Wednesday Nov 18 - 5:30-7:30pm
Single speed/fixed gear are the best winter commuters because for their simplicity, time to learn how to build one from scratch! This workshop will mostly focus on how to convert an old road frame into a nice and handy single speed/fixed gear commuter. What pieces should you change? What parts can you keep and use until their end? We will also talk about the common problems encountered with a conversion, as well as some "security" basics concerning cops that you should know when riding a fixed gear.
Free workshop open to the public, including volunteers. Limited space - RSVP to theflat.bikecollective@gmail.com to attend.
The Flat Bike Collective Visioning Meeting
Friday Nov 20 - 6-10pm
25 Beaubien E
A biannual party-meeting of free dinner, communal drinking, deep discussion on the Flat's past, present, and future; followed by optional wild partying.
Winterizing Workshop
Wednesday Dec 2 - 5-7:30pm(not November, but really close!)
Bike mods, maintenance and general tips to keep you up and running this winter!
Free workshop open to the public, including volunteers. Limited space - RSVP to theflat.bikecollective@gmail.com to attend.
Cheers,
The Flat fam

item.title: We'll be closed this Monday
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: On account of some building maintenance we'll be closed this Monday. (Dec 7) Sorry for the short notice!

item.title: Fall Hours and Other Exciting News
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: Learn to work on your own bike with our friendly advice - we're openMonday, Tuesday, and Thursday from 5:00pm-7:30pm. If you are in the market for a new bike, we have bikes for less than $100! With a little elbow grease you could be the proud new owner of a solid set of wheels. See the bikes available here!

item.title: Stay safe and warm this winter!
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: Don't let the weather get you down, swing by in person to get advice for biking through the winter during our open hours or get advice on ourfacebook page! Open hours Monday, Tuesday, Thursday @ 5:00pm-7:30pm

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thank youuu

item.title: Moving! - UPDATE!
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: UPDATE: we got an extension to our lease that's good for the next 6 months. However, if you know of anywhere near McGill that could be a potential place for us, please let us know... See you in the basement of 2075 Robert-Bourassa for now! ---Original post--- Hi everyone, our time at 2075 Robert-Bourassa is coming to an end on March 30. We are somewhat frantically looking for a new space to house us, but so far anything that appeared promising has fallen through. If we can't find a space, we'll have to go on hiatus, which would be super not ideal since it is just about to be bike season! If anyone has any leads for available spaces near McGill (since we are a McGill Service, technically), please let us know!! THANK YOU

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Thanks!

item.title: Summer hours - often irregular!
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: Summer semester is here, which means a lot of our volunteers are not in town. Whether it's RAships, field schools, work, or vacation, people are not around as regularly as in the fall and winter terms. As an entirely volunteer-run organisation, this is inevitable. It also means that often, we won't be able to open 3 days a week. Please check our facebook page (you don't need fb to see our page!) for our most up-to-date schedule. We'll try to post the weekend before each new week with what days we'll be operational. Thanks for your understanding!

item.title: Closed until further notice
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
Hi everyone,
Due to the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic, The Flat will be closed until further notice. We all have to do our part in social distancing. Keep in touch with your people, and bike safe! <3

item.title: Moving back to campus...
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: We're still not operating, but as Covid restrictions allow (both McGill's and Qubec's), we are in the process of getting settled back into our original space in the basement of the SSMU building, ie 3480 rue MacTavish. Thanks to the volunteers and SSMU building service team who helped get our tool board back into the workshop Next up: non fire hazard shelving...

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Yai!!! Congrats

item.title: Stay tuned.....
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: Thank y'all so much for your continued patience and support while we are closed.. This website will be updated Very Soon (think: before Oct 4) to reflect our reopening plan! Also remember to follow us on instagram @theflatbikecollective !

item.title: Reopening!
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: We will probably re-open with either Monday Oct 11th or Monday Oct 18th 5.00pm - 7.30pm! We are using a same-day appointment system and you can sign up here. Proof of Vaccination will be required and unfortunately we can only have 2 users at a time at our SSMU basement space. For more information, you could visit here. We can't wait to see you! (follow our ins @theflatbikecollective !)

item.title: !!!OPEN NOW!!!
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
I AM SO HAPPY to announce our hours the week of Oct 18:
Monday Oct 18: 5.00 pm to 7.30 pm
Tuesday Oct 19: Closed to public, volunteers will focus on breathing new lives into abandoned campus bikes.
Thursday Oct 21: 5.00 pm to 7.30 pm

After our REOPENING week the up-to-date hours will be posted here.
Note we are adopting a same day appointment system. Please read the instructions and sign up here.
Lastly, we are always looking for new volunteers!

item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: {"version":2,"isGlobalStylesUserThemeJSON":true}

item.title: Happy New Year!!!
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: Hi dear members of the FLAT community, I hope y'all had a wonderful winter break! Now that we are all back, I have bad news: based on the latest info from SSMU (Jan 4,) University Center will be closed for the month of January. I know this would be difficult for those of us who bike through winter (like myself,) bear with us as we wait for more updates from SSMU. In the meantime, stay warm, bike safe, follow health measures, and hopefully see you soon!

item.title: Good News!!!!
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: Hi folks!!! We submitted our re-opening plan to SSMU and Building Admin! It was approved! And re can reopen! Be sure to check out our Contact/Hours page! We still use the same-day appointment system! Interested in volunteering? Send us a message on FB/INS, or an email, or drop by!

item.title: Tuesdays are back!!!
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded: Well, technically, Tuesdays never left.... But in our meeting today we decided to not call Tuesday bike building days and return it to be *normal* open days. (Starting Tuesday May 24th, you can come in on Tuesdays with your bikes!) We are also experimenting with a different Tuesday opening hour: 4.00pm to 6.00 pm to be more accessible to different schedules! (Will change (or not?) based on reaction) Thanks for reading our website!

item.title: End of Year Bike Picnic
item.dc:creator: bikecollective
item.content:encoded:
Come celebrate the end of another awesome year of cooperative bike maintenance with our end of year bike picnic!
When: Wednesday 26th of April @ noon
Where: Meet outside the SSMU building, we'll decide a location for the picnic together based on the weather and people's interests!
Who: Everyone is welcome!
Bring food to share and your best energy! See you Wednesday!
